body_html:
This is the strategy the the Julia client takes to get around the limited number of gradients implemented in C++.

When a user requests gradients, the current graph is serialized and sent to a Python process. The Python process then adds gradient operations to the graph, serializes it, and sends it back to the Julia client. A little round-about, but it works.
body_text:
This is the strategy the the Julia client takes to get around the limited number of gradients implemented in C++.
When a user requests gradients, the current graph is serialized and sent to a Python process. The Python process then adds gradient operations to the graph, serializes it, and sends it back to the Julia client. A little round-about, but it works.
body:
This is the strategy the [the Julia client](https://github.com/malmaud/TensorFlow.jl) takes to get around the limited number of gradients implemented in C++.

When a user requests gradients, the current graph is serialized and sent to a Python process. The Python process then adds gradient operations to the graph, serializes it, and sends it back to the Julia client. A little round-about, but it works.
